Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Impact of Convectively-Generated Gravity Waves on Mesoscale Convective Systems
Award.AbstractNarration:
Gravity waves, generated by thunderstorms, are commonly associated with nighttime thunderstorm clusters called "Mesoscale Convective Systems" (MCSs); storm systems that are frequent producers of heavy rainfall and damaging winds. These gravity waves modify both the environment surrounding the MCS and its internal circulation. Considering that even small changes in the surrounding environment or internal circulation have been shown to affect MCS development, improved understanding of these wave processes is important to successful MCS prediction. Gravity waves have been linked to storm intensification and potential severe weather, so improved understanding of these features would lead to improved immediate, short-term forecasts of severe weather risks. This research supports an early career female investigator and one graduate student, and also involves a collaboration between a university and private industry involved in atmospheric research.

Knowledge of the MCS gravity wave generation-feedback process, including the influence of microphysical perturbations on this process, will lead to better understanding of MCS development, as well as the sensitivity of convection to these environmental changes. Understanding the extent to which changes in the environment due to convectively generated gravity waves need to be captured to correctly simulate MCSs is a significant step to understanding MCS predictability. Furthermore, knowledge of the gravity wave characteristics produced by an MCS allows inferences to be made about the phase, depth, and intensity of the latent heating profile without direct microphysical observations that can be resource-intensive to obtain. Understanding of the influence of microphysical perturbations upon the generation and impacts of gravity waves will be useful in microphysical parameterization development, leading to better numerical model prediction of convection in general. Model simulations will be compared against actual data from the Plains Elevated Convection at Night (PECAN) Field Campaign.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of this project was to understand how thunderstorms organized into a line, or Mesoscale Convective Systems (MCSs), can produce specfic atmospheric waves, otherwise known as gravity waves, in response to microphysical phase changes inside the storm. Using idealized simulations, specific types of gravity waves were found to be produced when an MCS first developed an updraft, precipitation first reached the ground, stratiform-type precipitation extended rearward from the convective line, and mid-level winds flowing in the rear of the storm system increased.  These waves modified the environment ahead of the MCS by either stabilizing or destabilizing the air; these modifications subsequently affect the MCS in two different ways.

Early on in an MCS lifecycle a few gravity waves were generated in a consistent pattern. These waves directly modified air flowing into the updraft causing the updraft to either intensify or weaken. As the MCS reached maturity, however, more gravity waves were generated with less regularity. These waves would work in concert with other, high frequency waves to initiate new convection in advance of the system. After this new convection was absorbed back into the MCS the updraft would strengthen. Depending on the initial environmental conditions or microphysical parameterization used in the simulations, the speed of the transition between these two phases could change. Different vertical placement of the microphysical cooling, as a result of a different microphysical parameterization, could also change the type of waves produced in the second phase.

Review of low-level observations from the Plains Elevated Convection at Night (PECAN) field campaign revealed multiple types of gravity waves associated with MCSs traveling through the domain. Because the observational changes associated with these waves were subtle, observations of a wave at multiple locations, moving at a coherent, realistic speed were necessary to confirm their existence.

The production of these waves and their subsequent feedbacks explain how MCSs can maintain convective updraft intensity over time despite indices traditionally associated with MCS longevity, such as cold pool strength and low-level environmental shear, indicating convective updraft dissipation. These results also show that microphysical parameterization changes can have effects on the environment around convection, in addition to within the convection itself.  Such results represent an important paradigm shift when forecasting MCS intensity and longevity.
